thread.title: Newspaper headlines: House sales 'slump' and NHS staff 'crisis'
thread.title_full: Newspaper headlines: House sales 'slump' and NHS staff 'crisis'

title: Newspaper headlines: House sales 'slump' and NHS staff 'crisis'
text: Messenger Image caption The Times says inflated asking prices and economic uncertainty is causing the housing market to stall in parts of the UK, including southern and north-east England. Estate agents forecast the number of home transactions completed this year will fall by 11%, reports the paper. Image caption The i says there is a looming staff crisis in the NHS in England. An investigation by the paper suggests government plans to recruit more GPs are struggling to keep pace with retirement, while figures show nurse recruitment levels have fallen. Image caption The Daily Mail concentrates on planned changes in business rates - carrying a warning from a wine merchant that increased expenses faced by some small businesses could turn high streets into a "retail wasteland". The paper calls Tom Innes the "shopkeeper who spoke for Britain". Image caption The Daily Telegraph reports former trade secretaries Lord Tebbit, Sir Vince Cable and Dame Margaret Beckett are demanding reforms to the business rate reforms. Lord Tebbit is calling for a cabinet committee to consider solutions amid pressure on ministers to make changes, it says. Image caption The Guardian leads on Tony Blair's call for Britons to "rise up" and change their minds on Brexit. The paper says the former PM's speech sparked a backlash from Labour MPs for fuelling party divisions ahead of two by-elections in constituencies that voted leave. Image caption The Daily Express calls Tony Blair "arrogant". It says a poll suggests that support to "get on with" Brexit is growing despite the former PM's "desperate bid" to urge voters to think again. Image caption The Daily Mirror says a report by the gambling watchdog into how a convicted rapist tricked his way to a lottery jackpot has been heavily redacted. The paper maintains there are still unanswered questions about the incident. Image caption The Sun describes Ray Woodhall as the "miracle dad" - reporting how he "died" 27 times but is now on the mend. The father-of-three had a heart attack playing football and had 26 more after being taken to hospital, it says. Image caption The Daily Star leads on the confirmation that EastEnders star Danny Dyer is taking a break from the BBC soap. It also carries the news that Elvis Presley's grandchildren have been taken into care in the US. Lisa Marie Presley's estranged husband has issued a statement denying claims made about him in divorce proceedings. Image caption The Financial Times leads with Unilever's rejection of a Â£115bn takeover bid by Kraft Heinz. It says the stage is set for a battle between two of the largest consumer goods companies in the world.
